es_results_raw: Esto puede ser cierto, puesto que cuando los magiares conquistaron el país, trajeron consigo una mezcla de tradiciones y costumbres que se fusionaron con las ya existentes. Aunque los sajones y los valacos también han dejado su huella en la región, los escequelios se consideran los guardianes de la historia antigua. Esta identidad única ha hecho que Transilvania sea un lugar de interés para los historiadores y los viajeros curiosos. Sin embargo, la vida en esta región no es siempre fácil, ya que las diferencias culturales a menudo llevan a tensiones. A pesar de esto, la gente de Transilvania ha aprendido a convivir, creando una sociedad rica en diversidad y tradiciones. Cada grupo tiene su propio espacio y sus propias costumbres, pero también hay momentos en los que todos se unen para celebrar festivales y eventos comunes que refuerzan lazos entre las diferentes nacionalidades.

Esto no podía ser cierto, porque hasta esos momentos lo había entendido perfectamente; por lo menos respondía a mis preguntas exactamente como si las entendiera. Él y su mujer, la anciana que me había recibido, se miraron con temor. Él murmuró que
es_second_half: el dinero le había sido enviado en una carta, y que era todo lo que sabía. Cuando le pregunté si conocía al Conde Drácula y si podía decirme algo de su castillo, tanto él como su mujer se persignaron, y diciendo que no sabían nada de nada, se negaron simplemente a decir nada más. Era ya tan cerca a la hora de la partida que no tuve tiempo de preguntarle a nadie más, pero todo me parecía muy misterioso y de ninguna manera tranquilizante.
es_results_raw: Él murmuró que el conde no debía saber que él había hablado conmigo. Su mirada era evasiva, y su esposa, la anciana, asintió con la cabeza, como si compartiera su miedo. "No debemos hablar de esto," susurró ella, con una voz que temblaba ligeramente. "El conde es poderoso, y si él supiera...". El posadero parecía a punto de decir algo más, pero se detuvo, como si temiera que cada palabra que saliera de su boca pudiera traer consecuencias impredecibles. Me quedé allí, inmóvil, intentando procesar lo que acababa de oír. ¿Qué secretos ocultaban? ¿Qué peligro acechaba? La atmósfera en la posada se había vuelto tensa, y el silencio que siguió a sus palabras era tan denso que casi podía cortarlo con un cuchillo. Finalmente, el posadero se giró hacia mí, con una expresión que intentaba parecer tranquila, pero que no engañaba. "No te preocupes, todo estará bien. El conde es un hombre justo, y él siempre cumple con sus promesas." Sin embargo, su voz no sonaba convencida, y su mirada evitaba la mía. Me pregunté cuántas veces habría mentido para proteger secretos que ni siquiera entendía. La noche cayó sobre la posada, y con ella, un manto de incertidumbre que parecía imposible de romper.

Her lips were parted, and she was breathing—not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath. As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat. Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold. I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her. At first she did not respond; but gradually she became more and
en_second_half: more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly, till finally she opened her eyes and awoke. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was. Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace. She trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As we passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince. She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not. However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.

en_first_half: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he
en_second_half: could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”

I could see the tension in his body as he slowly lowered the weapon. The guard then handcuffed him, and with a nod to me, he led him out of the room. The incident was reported to the hospital administration, and I was left to tend to my injured wrist. The doctor who treated me later remarked that the cut was not as severe as it could have been, but it was a stark reminder of the unpredictable nature of my patients. In the days that followed, I found myself reflecting on the incident, questioning the nature of my profession and the trust placed in me. It was a humbling experience, one that made me more cautious and empathetic in my approach to my patients. The hospital underwent a review of its security measures, and stricter protocols were put in place to prevent such incidents. Despite the added security, I remained vigilant, always aware that the line between healer and protector is often thin and fragile. The incident became a part of my professional history, a reminder of the challenges and responsibilities that come with my role.

es_first_half: 17 de septiembre. Estaba ocupado, después de cenar, en mi estudio fechando mis libros, los cuales, debido a la urgencia de otros trabajos y a las muchas visitas a Lucy, se encontraban tristemente atrasados. De pronto, la puerta se abrió de golpe y mi paciente entró como un torbellino, con el rostro deformado por la ansiedad. Yo me sobresalté, pues es una cosa casi desconocida que un paciente entre de esa manera y por su propia cuenta en el despacho del superintendente. Sin hacer ninguna pausa se dirigió directamente hacia mí. En su mano había un cuchillo de cocina, y como vi que era peligroso, traté de mantener la mesa entre nosotros. Sin embargo, fue demasiado rápido y demasiado fuerte para mí; antes de que yo pudiera alcanzar mi equilibrio me había lanzado el primer golpe, cortándome bastante
es_second_half: profundamente la muñeca izquierda. Pero antes de que pudiera lanzarme otro golpe, le di un derechazo y cayó con los brazos y piernas extendidos por el suelo. Mi muñeca sangraba profusamente, y un pequeño charco se formó sobre la alfombra. Vi que mi amigo no parecía intentar otro esfuerzo, por lo que me ocupé en vendar mi muñeca, manteniendo todo el tiempo una cautelosa vigilancia sobre la figura postrada. Cuando mis asistentes entraron corriendo y pusimos nuestra atención sobre él, su aspecto positivamente me enfermó. en_second_half: I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula. The house looked as though it had been long untenanted. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. Tôi có thể kể cho mọi người nghe một câu chuyện mà tôi đã từng đọc. Chuyện là thế này: Có một quý ngài sở hữu một biệt thự tuyệt đẹp ở Luân Đôn. Mùa hè năm đó, do có việc phải đi Thụy Sĩ trong một thời gian khá lâu, khoảng dăm bảy tháng gì đó, ông đã chủ quan khóa cửa nhà trước khi lên đường và chẳng cần nhờ ai trông nom hết. Kết quả là sau khi ông đi được một thời gian ngắn, có kẻ trộm đã đập vỡ kính một ô cửa sổ nhìn ra vườn rồi đột nhập vào trong. Tay chủ thầu đã bàn với hắn phá bỏ ngôi nhà vào một ngày cụ thể để cất lên một tòa nhà mới. Chỉ buồn cho người chủ thật sự của ngôi nhà, từ Thụy Sĩ về, trước mắt ông chỉ còn là một cái hố vĩ đại thế chỗ cho ngôi nhà thân quen của ông. Lão già đi trước chúng tôi, nhưng lão không thể chạy nhanh hơn chiếc quan tài của mình. Chúng tôi đã học được từ Mina rằng, trong mọi tình huống, sự bình tĩnh và sự chuẩn bị kỹ lưỡng là chìa khóa. No podemos permitirnos el lujo de cometer errores, ya que cada movimiento que hagamos será crucial. Mina ha demostrado que la perspicacia y la paciencia son nuestras mejores aliadas. Su capacidad para ver lo que otros no ven es una lección que no podemos olvidar. Esta vez, no hay margen para el error. Cada paso que demos, cada decisión que tomemos, será determinante para nuestro éxito. La caja, aunque fuerte, tiene sus puntos débiles, y nosotros, con la guía de Mina, estamos listos para descubrirlos. La victoria está al alcance de nuestra mano, pero solo si mantenemos la calma y la concentración.

Chúng ta cần phải học cách hợp tác, ngay cả khi chúng ta không hoàn toàn tin tưởng lẫn nhau. Sự thật là, trong thế giới này, không ai có thể chiến thắng một mình. Hãy nhớ rằng, đôi khi, sự yếu đuối thực sự là sức mạnh, và sức mạnh thực sự là sự kiên nhẫn. Hãy luôn sẵn sàng học hỏi và điều chỉnh chiến lược của mình.

en_first_half: 31 October.—Arrived at Veresti at noon. The Professor tells me that this morning at dawn he could hardly hypnotise me at all, and that all I could say was: “dark and quiet.” He is off now buying a carriage and horses. He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so that we may be able to change them on the way. We have something more than 70 miles before us.
en_second_half: The country is lovely, and most interesting; if only we were under different conditions, how delightful it would be to see it all. If Jonathan and I were driving through it alone what a pleasure it would be. To stop and see people, and learn something of their life, and to fill our minds and memories with all the colour and picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint people! But, alas!—
en_results_raw: After a few hours, the Professor returns with a sturdy carriage and a pair of fresh horses. He seems excited about the prospect of our journey, though I can't help but feel a twinge of anxiety. The Professor assures me that the road is well-traveled, but I can't shake the feeling that something is amiss. As we prepare to leave, he hands me a small leather pouch, instructing me to keep it close at all times. I ask him what it contains, but he merely smiles and says it's a precaution. The sun is beginning to set, casting long shadows across the landscape. We set off, the horses' hooves pounding rhythmically against the road. Despite the Professor's confidence, I can't help but wonder what lies ahead. The journey is long, and the night is drawing in, but we press on, driven by a sense of urgency that neither of us dares to question. As we travel deeper into the countryside, the air grows colder, and the silence becomes oppressive. The Professor occasionally glances at me, as if he senses my unease, but says nothing. The night stretches on, and the miles seem to pass by in a blur. By the time we reach our destination, the first light of dawn is just beginning to break, and I find myself both relieved and exhausted.

Ông đã đi mua một chiếc xe và vài con ngựa tăng viện - nếu có thể - để thay phiên kéo trên đường. Chặng đường chúng tôi đi

Giá như tôi và Jonathan cùng được sánh bước trên đường thì lãng mạn biết nhường nào! Ôi những con người xa lạ, những cảnh vật thần tiên và hoang dại kia!... • Một lúc sau

Tôi cố gắng giữ cho mình tỉnh táo, nhưng sự mệt mỏi đã bắt đầu lấn át. Giáo sư đã không ngừng động viên tôi, nói rằng chúng tôi sẽ đến được nơi an toàn. Khi mặt trời dần lặn, ánh hoàng hôn dần dần thay thế ánh sáng ban ngày. Tôi cảm thấy mình như đang bước vào một thế giới khác, nơi mà mọi thứ đều trở nên chậm rãi và yên tĩnh. Khi chúng tôi đến gần thị trấn, tôi nhận ra rằng những con đường đã trở nên quen thuộc hơn. Giáo sư đã chuẩn bị mọi thứ rất chu đáo, và tôi cảm thấy mình may mắn khi có ông ở bên. Khi chúng tôi đến nơi, tôi cảm thấy như mình đã vượt qua một thử thách lớn. Những người dân ở đó đã chào đón chúng tôi một cách thân thiện, và tôi cảm thấy như mình đã tìm thấy một nơi mới để gọi là nhà.

El profesor me dice que esta mañana, al amanecer, a duras penas pudo hipnotizarme, y que todo lo que pude decir fue: "oscuro y tranquilo". Ahora está fuera, comprando una calesa y caballos; dice que más tarde tratará de comprar más caballos, de manera que podamos cambiarlos en el camino. Nos quedan todavía ciento diez kilómetros
es_second_half: por recorrer. El paisaje es precioso y muy interesante; si nos encontráramos en diferentes circunstancias, ¡qué encantador resultaría contemplar todo esto! Si Jonathan y yo viajáramos solos por estas tierras, ¡qué placer sería! Podríamos detenernos, veríamos a la gente, aprenderíamos algo sobre ella y llenaríamos nuestras mentes con todo lo pintoresco y el colorido del campo salvaje y hermoso y las personas tan singulares. Pero, ¡ay…!

La tarde es fría y el viento sopla con fuerza, haciendo que las hojas de los árboles crujan en el aire. El profesor regresa con la calesa y los caballos, y mientras se prepara para la jornada de mañana, me habla de los peligros que podríamos encontrar en el camino. Me explica que Veresti no es solo un punto geográfico, sino un lugar cargado de historias y secretos que han sido transmitidos de generación en generación. Dice que es importante que estemos preparados para lo que pueda encontrarnos, ya que el camino que nos espera no será fácil. Mientras tanto, el cielo se oscurece rápidamente y las estrellas comienzan a aparecer, iluminando el paisaje con su luz fría y distante. El profesor se despide y se dirige a la estación, prometiéndome que mañana todo será diferente, que el miedo y la incertidumbre se habrán disipado. La noche es larga y el silencio absoluto solo rompe el viento que sigue soplando con fuerza. A la mañana siguiente, el profesor vuelve con una sonrisa en el rostro, y me dice que todo está listo para partir. Nos subimos a la calesa y partimos hacia el desconocido, con el profesor al volante y yo sentado a su lado, sintiendo el frío del aire y el temor de lo que podría esperarnos.

Durup insanları görmek, yaşamlarına ilişkin bir şeyler öğrenmek, zihnimizi ve anılarımızı bu vahşi, güzel topraklar ve ilginç insanların tüm renkleri ve etkileyiciliğiyle doldurmak! Ama heyhat!

Profesör bana, "Dikkatli ol, her an tehlike olabilir," diye fısıldadı. Yolda karşılaştığımız her kasaba, her köy, sadece bir kafes gibi görünüyor. Herkesin gözleri sizi izliyor, herkesin sesi duyuluyor. Yolculuk bana, sadece bir yolculuk değil, bir mücadeleye dönüşüyor. Her adımın sonucunu bilmeden ilerliyoruz. Bu yolculuk, sadece fiziksel zorluklar değil, zihinsel zorluklarla da dolu. Her dakika, her adım, sadece bir adım daha atabilir miyiz diye düşünüyoruz. Bu yolculuk, sadece Profesör ve benim için değil, herkes için bir ders. Düşünceye, özgürlüğe ve özgüvene dair bir ders.

en_first_half: Later.—Dr. Van Helsing has returned. He has got the carriage and horses; we are to have some dinner, and to start in an hour. The landlady is putting us up a huge basket of provisions; it seems enough for a company of soldiers. The Professor encourages her, and whispers
en_second_half: to me that it may be a week before we can get any good food again. He has been shopping too, and has sent home such a wonderful lot of fur coats and wraps, and all sorts of warm things. There will not be any chance of our being cold.
en_results_raw: Dr. Van Helsing leans in closer, his eyes gleaming with a mixture of excitement and urgency. "We must be cautious," he whispers, his voice barely above a murmur. "The creature is cunning, and we cannot afford to make any mistakes. We must ensure that our plan is foolproof. The Professor nods in agreement, his brow furrowed with concentration. "Agreed, but we also need to be swift. Every moment counts. We must not let our guard down, even for a second. The landlady, overhearing their conversation, looks concerned but remains silent, her hands trembling slightly as she continues to pack the basket. The Professor pats her reassuringly on the shoulder. "Do not worry, madam. We will take care of everything. Just focus on preparing our supplies. We will need every bit of this food and equipment. The carriage is ready, and the horses are well-rested. We are prepared for whatever lies ahead." Dr. Van Helsing glances at his watch. "In one hour, we will be on our way. Let us hope that our preparations have been sufficient. The Professor and I will lead the way, but we need everyone to stay alert and follow our instructions to the letter. The landlady, still packing, nods her head, her eyes filled with a mixture of fear and determination. "I will do my best, gentlemen. You can count on me." As the hour approaches, the atmosphere in the room grows tense, a palpable sense of anticipation hanging in the air. The Professor and Dr. Van Helsing exchange a glance, both knowing that what lies ahead will test their skills and courage to the utmost.
